content.description: Follow the Flake up the face of the boulder, smearing for footholds. At the top of the boulder, where the tree is, transition to the chickenheads to the right of the flake for the finish, and top out on to the boulder.
content.location: The middle of the Babs Boulder, an obvious flake.

content.description: Using some pockets and rails for footholds, haul yourself up over the overhanging "triangle", then edge up, using the various rails as you go up, to the top out.

Use the crack (same as Lightning Strikes Twice) for your right hand and the nubbins to the left for your left hand. A lot of smearing for footholds, Work your way up, topping out just to the left of the block on top of the boulder.
content.location: Directly to the left of Lightning Strikes Twice

content.description: On the far left edge of the boulder, there is a ramp. Use the iron rails and edge of the boulder to stem against the ramp until you top out.
content.location: Far left end of the Babs boulder.

content.description: Fun, Sharp climb on chickenheads that goes up next to "Lightning Strikes Twice" and actually finishes on the same place. It will rip up your hands however, because of some sharp crimps and jugs.
content.location: To the right of "Lightning Strikes Twice"

content.description: A mossy arete that is straddled to ascend. Fun, plus the moss shields your hands from the sharpness of the rock
content.location: At the far right end of the Babs Boulder

content.description: North Facing Boulder, has potential for multiple lines on a slabby (75-80 degree) face. Has the best line (in my humble opinion at least) in a fifteen mile radius, a beautiful flake that shoots up the rock about 8 feet, with amazing slabby footholds and an interesting finish. Probably the best face overall though, or at least a tie with the Baby Babs Boulder. Generally very mossy, but it doesn't hurt the climbing, so please, no cleaning the moss beyond unintentional wearing away
